dt: {bc}to summon into court to warrant or defend a title
{bc}to verify (a business transaction) by examining documentary evidence
{bc}to cite or refer to as authority or supporting evidence

pt: {sc}certify{/sc} {sc}attest{/sc} {sc}witness{/sc} {sc}vouch{/sc} mean to testify to the truth or genuineness of something. {sc}certify{/sc} usually applies to a written statement, especially one carrying a signature or seal.

pt.t: {it}certified{/it} that the candidate had met all requirements

pt: {sc}attest{/sc} applies to oral or written testimony usually from experts or witnesses.

pt.t: {it}attested{/it} to the authenticity of the document

pt: {sc}witness{/sc} applies to the subscribing of one's own name to a document as evidence of its genuineness.
{sc}vouch{/sc} applies to one who testifies as a competent authority or a reliable person.

et: Middle English {it}vochen, vouchen{/it}, from Anglo-French {it}voucher{/it} to call, vouch, from Latin {it}vocare{/it} to call, summon, from {it}vox{/it} voice {ma}{mat|voice|}{/ma}
shortdef: to supply supporting evidence or testimony
to give a guarantee : become surety

dt: {bc}to say that (someone or something) is honest, true, or good

dt.t: I can {it}vouch for{/it} the authenticity of the document.
We'll {it}vouch for{/it} him. He's a good guy.

shortdef: to say that (someone or something) is honest, true, or good
